Authors:
Tomas Panek, Alastair GB Simpson, Vladimir Hampl, Ivan
Cepicka
Title:
Creneis carolina gen. et sp. nov. (Heterolobosea), a novel
marine anaerobic protist with strikingly derived morphology and life
cycle
Keywords:
Heterolobosea; anaerobiosis; ultrastructure; new species;
evolution; molecular phylogeny
Abstract:
We report the light-microscopic morphology and
ultrastructure of a novel free-living, heterotrophic protist, Creneis
carolina gen. et sp. nov. isolated from marine anoxic sediments. C.
carolina is a heterotrophic, obligately anaerobic amoeboid flagellate,
and superficially resembles Mastigamoeba (Amoebozoa: Archamoebae) or
Breviata (Breviatea) by possessing a single anterior flagellum. However,
its life cycle contains multiflagellate cells with unusual morphology.
The structure of the mastigont of C. carolina is unique and not readily
comparable with any eukaryotic group. Unexpectedly, phylogenetic
analyses of SSU rDNA and concatenate of Î±- and Î²-tubulin genes with
SSU rDNA convincingly showed that C. carolina is a member of
Heterolobosea and specifically belongs to Tetramitia.
